1113062736735330304.text: I’m on a panel today at the SAE/NHTSA cyber workshop talking about cyber validation of connected automobiles.pic.twitter.com/vZtYshNHvW

1112348067079114754.text: Their steering was jerky like when we controlled steering of cars but we were just injecting CAN messages and they had control of the ECU sending messages.  I always thought getting control of the ECU would give better control.  Our primitive version:https://youtu.be/FzM1nd1kjP4

1112348066240176128.text: Finally their steering control via autopilot hack is the most dangerous (and most difficult to pull off).  This was cool, but I'm surprised they didn't have more fine control.

1112348065346846720.text: Also, they don't talk about this, but presumably if there were cars in the oncoming lane, the autopilot would stop as it would still detect these vehicles.  Not sure I'd trust this with my life but just saying autopilot is more than lane keep assist.

1112348064520523776.text: In the lane switching attack, its pretty scary.  But it looks like you need a break in lane markings (i.e. an intersection).  I'm not sure I'd be trusting autopilot through an intersection when operating normally.

1112348063560073221.text: The wipers attack is interesting in theory, I encourage you to read the paper about it.  But in practice, if you can turn on my wipers, I don't really care.  In fact, whatever sensor is in my non-tesla does this once in a while on accident already.

1112348062620532737.text: Have you seen @keen_lab video about hacking tells autopilot?  Here are some thoughts I have about it.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6QSsKy0I9LE …

1111818678071422976.text: I was really interested in limitations an attacker would have in controlling the steering.  There is a limit based on what mode the transmission is in.  There might be a limit in when the car is NOT in adaptive cruise control mode but I couldn't understand the paper in that case.

1111818677391933441.text: It also talks about how you might be able to fool the autopilot algorithms (neural nets) by making physical changes in the real world.

1111818676561461250.text: Super interesting paper (as usual) by @keen_lab.  It talks about how Tesla autopilot works and how what happens if attacker can get code execution on it.  https://keenlab.tencent.com/en/whitepapers/Experimental_Security_Research_of_Tesla_Autopilot.pdf …

1026090019222638592.text: BONUS: Adventures in Automotive Networks and Control Units (2013) (with @nudehaberdasher) (rejected from Blackhat, given at Defcon).  Basics of how to sorta control a Ford and Toyota using CAN message injection.  Our first car hacking talk.  I'd put it in the middle of the list.

1026090018140553216.text: 1.  Remote exploitation of an unaltered passenger vehicle (2015) (with @nudehaberdasher).  The Jeep hack.  Made @a_greenberg cry.  Cost FCA a bunch of money.

1026090017008103424.text: 2.  Fuzzing the phone in your phone (2009) (with @collinrm).  How to fuzz SMS stack of phones.  Demoed remote root exploit against iPhone requiring no user interaction.  Also, remote bug against windows phone that nobody cared about.

1026090015846268928.text: 3.  Advanced CAN Injection Techniques For Vehicle Networks (2016) (with @nudehaberdasher).  Discussed why CAN message injection doesn't typically "just work".  Demonstrated how to fully control acceleration, braking, steering of a Jeep.

1026090014403379201.text: 4.  Don't stand so close to me - NFC hacking (2012).  Let me within a few inches of your android phone, and I get a shell.  Google says this is a feature not a bug.  Also found some bugs in Windows phones.  This was funded by CyberFastTrack!

1026090013287768066.text: 5.  Battery Firmware Hacking (2011).  Talked about getting persistent access to firmware of batteries on MacBooks.  Answered the question of whether rewriting battery firmware would let you catch a computer on fire.  It doesn't - which is good.

1026090012088193025.text: 6.  Hacking Leopard (2007).  OS X version "Leopard" was delayed and so still under NDA.  Instead I talked about the first iPhone exploit.  This was the first talk about iOS security ever, afaik.  Also, my only turbo talk.

1026090011014385664.text: 7. Fun and Games with Mac OS X and iPhone payloads (2009) (with @_snagg).  Used code signing vulnerability and in memory library loading to load payloads like meterpreter in iOS.  This was almost a disaster since I didn't know I needed a code signing bug until after talk was in.

1026090010003611653.text: 8, Crash analysis with bit blaze (2010) (with Noah Johnson). Used an academic tool to try to figure out how exploitable crashes were.  Tool was hard to use and haven't used it since.  Did drop a bunch of 0-days in the talk tho.

1026090008934080514.text: 9. Iron Chef: Fuzzing Challenge (2008) (hosted by Jacob West, with my teammate Jake Honoroff, judges @window, @michaelawsutton etc).  Live on stage find-a-vuln competition between static analysis tools and fuzzing tools.  Fun but stressful, ultimately fuzzing won :)

1026090007751274496.text: 10. A survey of remote automotive attack surfaces (2014) (with @nudehaberdasher). Looked at architecture of 7 different cars and talked about which would be easier/harder to hack.  Turns out Jeep was top of the list.

1026090006673272832.text: Thursday, I give my 11th Blackhat talk, come check it out.  Its about what me and @nudehaberdasher have learned securing self-driving cars over the last few years for 3 different companies.  Below are my other 10 talks listed in the order I like them.

1014892446495305733.text: If you want to be a car hacker, read our papers, the papers from UW, and those from Keen team.  Tinker with your car.  Replicate findings.  Try to do new stuff.  That is how you learn, and it takes more than a weekend. (4/4)

1014892444759011328.text: Car hacking is difficult and like any difficult subject, there is only so much benefit from playing with it for a few hours.  Afterwards, you go home with a smile on your face then quickly forget everything you learned. (3/4)

1014892443106496512.text: Car hack villages are fun but they don't get people to become practitioners or advance the state of the art, much like how lock pick villages don't create expert lock smiths or advance the state of the art. (2/4)

1014892441768513541.text: I'm a car hacker but you might be surprised to learn I'm not a huge fan of car hack villages. (1/4)

998982984501022721.text: In all @keen_lab again showing why its the leader in offensive car security research.  I hope they keep at it and release those details!  Great work.

998982982995148801.text: Remember kids, never try to replicate findings of a security researchers :p

998982981766262784.text: Also this from BMW "BMW Group and Tencent Keen Security Lab agree that any replication of this scenario by a third-party is considered a criminal act, as it requires interfering with the public mobile network"

998982979165806592.text: In their response, BMW say the attack is sophisticated and so "BMW Group considers the security level for our customers and produces ensured".  Basically their cars are safe as long as nobody smart tries to hack them.

998982977811042304.text: BTW, all of my interactions with BMW have not been great.  They tell me they don't need help from security researchers and that they'll never share how their security works.

998982976611520512.text: Me and @nudehaberdasher released full details of all our work and nobody ever used it for malicious purposes and that was three years ago.

998982974015238144.text: That is, anyone capable of setting up a base station and writing a remote exploit using NGTP over SMS can probably find a vulnerability in the firmware knowing one is there :)

998982972714954753.text: They decided not to release details.  To me, this makes it hard to really judge their work and considering the level of difficulty in pulling it off, doesn't buy much protection.

998982969997000704.text: Cool attack, its unclear if they got full cyber physical control (i.e. steering/brakes/acceleration) from the full chain.  My guess is no or they would have mentioned it.

998982968705277954.text: This requires "physical proximity", say 100 meters, but is a remote attack which can be chained together to talk to physical controlling ECUs with UDS messages.

998982967576932352.text: The biggest result of the research was the ability to send NGTP messages over SMS which led to remote code execution if a car was connected to their rogue base station.  This required no user interaction.

998982965995720704.text: It is unclear how much control they have with only UDS messages in this research or if they are still figuring it out.  In theory you could possibly reprogram an ECU on PT-CAN and send standard CAN messages from it.

998982964947095553.text: For Jeep/Ford/Toyota with UDS you can't physically control steering/brakes much.  The exception is the brakes-no-work attack.  But we used standard CAN messages (non-UDS) for most of our physical control injection attacks.

998982963659493376.text: The researchers figured out how to send arbitrary UDS CAN messages to the PT-CAN network through the gateway.  However, this restriction limits the physical control you can do.

998982961436520449.text: However, the head unit and other remote stuff is only on the K-CAN which doesn't have physical control systems like brakes, steering, etc.  This is good design.  There is a gateway module which separates it from the PT-CAN network.

998982959951642625.text: Every full cyber physical car attack always has a tricky part where you have to gain the ability to send CAN messages from the remote component.  The BMW seems easier than Tesla or Jeep because the gateway here runs QNX on ARM so you can log in and play.

998982958307569664.text: The browser exploit left me with more questions than answers.  You need to intercept cellular connections but beyond that does it need user interaction?  Is that package standard on all BMW or do you have to pay a service?  etc?

998982957267341312.text: The bluetooth attack seems pretty limited.  Requires headunit to be in pairing mode and also is only a crash and not an exploit I believe although its hard to tell since they didn't provide details (more on that later)

998982955799339008.text: The OBDII to ethernet trick was really unexpected and wild, but in practice the USB attack seems easier for the same level of access.

998982954553692161.text: Their USB dongle to ethernet trick for local attack is funny because that worked on the Jeep too.

998982952628473857.text: So @keen_lab just dropped a really awesome paper about hacking BMW cars.  Get it here: https://keenlab.tencent.com/en/Experimental_Security_Assessment_of_BMW_Cars_by_KeenLab.pdf ….  What follows in my analysis (1/21):

991164105485684736.text: In summary: cool research, hat-tip from me.  Remote vulnerability in some cases on the Internet.  Remote vulnerability over Wifi if you can join the network.  However, quite a ways from cyber physical control of vehicle.  Keep up the research everyone!

991164104030203904.text: Unlike Tesla and Jeep, the Audi's architecture separated the components from the High Speed bus where brakes/steering/etc live.  This would have required ANOTHER exploit to bypass.  The researchers did not bypass this either.

991164101341696002.text: BTW tesla (and jeep) have the same architecture.  @marcwrogers research was similar in they didn't bypass the v850, but later @keenteam1000 did exactly that like we did for Jeep.

991164100205056000.text: Again, the architecture of the headunit was QNX talking to a v850 chip over serial.  Again, it seems you could reflash the v850 chip.  They did not do this but speculated it was possible.

991164098900647936.text: They found a remote vulnerability in Audi head units but "An attacker can only abuse this vulnerability if the owner has the Audi connect service, and the ISP in the country of the owner allows client-to-client communication, or hands out public IPv4 addresses."

991164097440993280.text: They don't report the vulnerability details because it would be "irresponsible".  We reported full details and nobody ever got hacked by them in the last 3 years but :shrug:

991164096241336327.text: These cars didn't have Over The Air (OTA) updates for their headhunts.  If your device talks to the internet, it should be updatable over the internet.

991164095033495553.text: They looked at 2015 vehicles.  This is a big difference between car hacking and, say, browser hacking.  2015 is an old browser, but still a pretty new car.

991164093091532800.text: Cool new research out on car hacking: https://www.computest.nl/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/connected-car-rapport.pdf ….  Hang on or mute as I'll give my thoughts on it.
